title-group.article-title: Optical Investigation of Sooting Propensity of n-Dodecane Pilot/Lean-Premixed Methane Dual-Fuel Combustion in a Rapid Compression-Expansion Machine

abstract.p: The sooting propensity of dual-fuel combustion with n-dodecane pilot injection in a lean-premixed methane-air charge has been investigated using an optically accessible Rapid Compression-Expansion Machine (RCEM) to achieve engine-relevant pressure and temperature conditions at the start of pilot injection. A Diesel injector with a 100 μm single-hole coaxial nozzle, mounted at the cylinder periphery, has been employed to admit the pilot fuel.

The aim of this study was to enhance the fundamental understanding of soot formation and oxidation processes of n-dodecane in the presence of methane in the air charge by parametric variation of methane equivalence ratio, charge temperature, and pilot fuel injection duration. The influence of methane on ignition delay and flame extent of the pilot fuel jet has been determined by simultaneous excited-state hydroxyl radical (OH*) chemiluminescence and Schlieren imaging. The sooting behavior of the flame has been characterized using the 2D-DBI imaging methodology. The apparent soot black-body temperature has been measured 1D resolved along the injector axis by applying an imaging spectrograph.

Addition of methane into the air charge considerably prolongs the ignition delay with an increasing effect under less reactive conditions and with higher methane equivalence ratios. Therefore, the influence of methane on the formation of soot is twofold: in case of short pilot injection, the presence of methane was found to decrease the soot formation due to the leaner pilot fuel mixture at the time of ignition. For longer pilot fuel injections, methane enhances the soot production by decreasing oxygen availability and introducing additional carbon. In all cases, methane strongly defers the oxidation of soot due to the lower availability of oxygen.

caption.p: Sectional view of the RCEM and schematic of the operation principle of the oil-coupled free-floating working and balancing piston. Adapted from [33]. © SAE International
RCEM combustion chamber geometry. Dimensions in mm. © SAE International
General specifications of the RCEM. © SAE International

Piston position and in-cylinder pressure trace averaged over 100 nonreactive cycles. 1×σ variability of both traces is demonstrated by the shaded regions. Stroke of an engine running at 1200 rpm is shown with the gray-dashed line. Injection timing is marked with a green line. © SAE International

Overview of the operating conditions. Values in the middle column relate to trigger pressure threshold of 25 bar (dataset 1, 770-850 K TSOI); conditions in the right column relate to PSOI = 45 bar (dataset 2, 1000 K TSOI). © SAE International
Optical setup for simultaneous Schlieren and OH* chemiluminescence imaging. © SAE International
Optical setup for simultaneous DBI imaging and 1D flame spectroscopy acquisition. © SAE International

1D-spectroscopy processing approach: Raw and corrected spectrum (sp.) of a sooting combustion (left). The dashed lines represent the Planck fit of the black-body luminosity and the spline fit of the chemiluminescence intensity. Raw and corrected spectrum from a non-sooting combustion event (right). © SAE International
Ignition delay dependence on the methane equivalence ratio ϕCH4, variation of TSOI, and injection duration (error bars, ET = 700 μs; crosses, ET = 500 μs; circles, ET = 400 μs). © SAE International

Evolution of soot cloud optical thickness for three cases with similar ignition delay: 770 K ΦCH4 = 0 (upper row), 810 K ΦCH4 = 0.33 (middle row), and 850 K ΦCH4 = 0.59 (lower row). Pilot injection: ET = 700 μs, pinj = 600 bar. The black-dashed contour shows the boundary of the FoV as well as the ensemble-averaged Schlieren contours. The bottom plot shows the evolution of the total soot quantity in arbitrary units, estimated by integration of the DBI signal across the FoV. The time instant when part of the soot leaves the FoV is indicated with a black-dashed line. No extrapolation of the soot quantity outside the FoV has been attempted. © SAE International

Evolution of soot cloud optical thickness for variation of the premixed methane equivalence ratio at constant TSOI = 850 K: ΦCH4 = 0 (upper row), ΦCH4 = 0.33 (middle row), and ΦCH4 = 0.59 (lower row). Pilot injection: ET = 700 μs, pinj = 600 bar. The black-dashed contour shows the boundary of the FoV as well as the ensemble-averaged Schlieren contours. The bottom plot shows the evolution of the total soot quantity in arbitrary units, estimated by integration of the DBI signal across the FoV. The time instant when part of the soot leaves the FoV is indicated with a black-dashed line. © SAE International

Temporal evolution of the soot quantity within FoV, at TSOI = 850 K, for a variation of the background equivalence ratio for three different injection durations: ET = 400 μs (dotted line, quantity multiplied by 10), ET = 500 μs (dashed line, quantity multiplied by 10), and ET = 700 μs (full line). The range of ignition delays for different ϕCH4 and the EOI time instants are marked with arrows. © SAE International

1D spray model predicted quantity of the fuel exceeding the threshold equivalence ratio for a variation of injection duration (full line, ϕ = 1.5; dashed line, ϕ = 2; dash-dotted line, ϕ = 2.5). The time instants of the EOI are marked with vertical arrows. Horizontal arrows show the experimentally determined ignition delay range (ϕCH4 variation) for different TSOI. © SAE International

Evolution of soot cloud optical thickness for variation of the premixed methane equivalence ratio (TSOI = 1000 K): ΦCH4 = 0 (upper row), ΦCH4 = 0.33 (middle row), and ΦCH4 = 0.47 (lower row). Ensemble-averaged Schlieren contours are overlaid (black-dashed line). Pilot injection: ET = 300 μs, pinj = 1000 bar. The bottom diagram shows the evolution of the total soot quantity in arbitrary units, estimated by integration of the DBI signal across the visible field. © SAE International

Temporal evolution of the 1D-resolved line-of-sight Ts-app along the injector axis for a variation of premixed methane equivalence ratio. Conditions: TSOI = 1000 K, ET = 300 μs, and pinj = 1000 bar. © SAE International

Adiabatic flame temperature dependence on pilot fuel equivalence ratio (ϕn-C12) and ϕCH4 for TSOI = 1000 K conditions. The soot formation range for Diesel fuel (reproduced from [37]) is marked in gray. © SAE International

Left: Schematic of the two-layer soot cloud model for the estimation of the apparent temperature bias. Right: Model-based approximation of the apparent temperature bias relative to the mass-averaged soot temperature. Upper plot: Bias for a thin soot cloud (layer L1, KL = 0.1; layer L2, KL = 0.3). Lower plot: Bias for a thick soot core (layer L1, KL = 0.1; layer L2, KL = 2). © SAE International

Temporal evolution of the 1D-resolved line-of-sight Ts_app along the injector axis for a variation of premixed methane equivalence ratio. Pilot injection: ET = 700 μs, pinj = 600 bar. © SAE International
Dependence of average Ts-app on TSOI, ϕCH4, and injection duration (ET). © SAE International
Geometry of the test setup for the characterization of the methane distribution in the RCEM prior to compression. © SAE International
Single-shot mixing evolution for six times after SOI (5 ms, 100 ms, 200 ms, 500 ms, 1500 ms, 4000 ms) normalized to the homogeneous concentration signal. © SAE International
Average (50 repetitions) distribution of methane 4 s after injection, normalized with a fully homogeneous concentration. © SAE International

Histogram of detected methane concentrations at a time 4 s after SOI, normalized to fully homogeneous concentration. Red line indicated the standard deviation of the histogram (σ = 0.068). © SAE International
Optical and quantum efficiency of the relevant elements in the 1D-spectroscopy optical path. © SAE International
